title: Today's class is all about: the Hotel Reception!

license.name: CC Naamsvermelding 4.0 Internationale licentie
license.description: De Internationale Creative Commons 4.0 licentie waarbij de gebruiker het werk mag kopiëren, verspreiden en doorgeven en afgeleide werken mag maken onder de voorwaarde: Naamsvermelding, zie http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/.

items.content:
What are we going to do today?

How great that you are here again!

In this lesson, we're going to learn about how you, as a future hotel receptionist, can help a guest in English!

We can all remember those times our parents or ourselves had to talk or ask a question at the hotel desk when we were on vacation.

Of course, this was perhaps a simple task for you as a guest, but have you ever paid attention to the receptionists and how much they need to know and communicate in English at the desk?

Well, now this could sound complex, but hopefully, at the end of this lesson, you will be better prepared to help an English-speaking guest at the hotel desk!

For today

In this lesson, we will learn how to help and guide English-speaking guests in a hotel + how to do everyday work activities in English!

Once you have gone through all the material that applies to you, you make an exam at the end to find out what you actually learned and what you perhaps have to learn more about!

Every year/ level student has their own exam. If you want or if you are done with your material early, you can go through all the other material as well, but this is not mandatory. It does however give you a good insight into the following lessons and what you ultimately need to be able to do at the end of year three.

First-year students, level 3 and 4:

At the end of this class, I will...

  • ...better understand the role of the hotel reception

  • ...be able to help a guest with giving directions

For the second-year students, level 3

At the end of this class, I will have...

  • *same as the above can-do's

  • ...better understand how to help a guest with giving directions

  • ...better understand how to help a guest with frequently asked questions

  • ...better understand how to help a guest with complaints

For the second-year students, level 4

At the end of this class, I will have...

  • *same as the above can-do's

  • ...had an introduction to the check-in and check-out process

heading.content: Day in the Life of a: Hotel Receptionist

items.content:
The work activities of a hotel receptionist

Hotel receptionists greet guests and welcome them to the hotel! You are the first and last person guests see during their stay which means that you are the representation of the company.

In addition to checking in and checking out visitors, you are also involved in activities such as: confirming reservations, explaining the hotel amenities, giving directions to rooms, handling complaints, and creating room keys.

Like we saw in the video before; giving directions through the hotel, city, and answering hotel-related questions are, next to checking in and checking out guests, one of the most common work activities you'll have to do!

To better prepare you for these work activities, we will go through some scenarios by making either fill-in the gap, multiple-choice, open questions or, drag questions assignments.

Were you unable to complete the assignment in one go? Don't worry! You can always try again.

In the end, you'll have to make an exam to test your knowledge altogether!

Giving directions to a guest is one of the most common work activities because the guests are most often, for the first time in the city you work at and don't know where anything around them is.

This is where you step in for them and help them!

These are some basic phrases and examples you can use:

1. Go straight/ left, turn straight/ left, go past,

2. Turn left when you see the restaurant called....

3. Turn left at the supermarket.

4. Go past the cinema and you'll find the library.

5. Turn right on the next corner.

prompt.body: Help the guest get to the city centre by giving them the right directions.

content.body: Guest: Okay, that is fine. How do I get there?
Guest: I would like to walk there if it is not far.
Guest: Oh okay, thank you and goodbye.
You: Once you have turned right, you walk for about 5 minutes until you get to the cinema called: 'CINESTOCK'
You: The city center is across the street from the cinema.
You: Hello. How can I help you?
You: If you were to walk, it would take about 15 minutes
You: Then, walk for about 5 minutes until you get to the restaurant called: Tiny Turtle, and across the street and turn right.
You: Once you leave the hotel, take a left to turn the corner.
Guest: Yes, hello. I would like to know the way to the city center.
You: Good luck and have a nice day.
You: Okay. So there are multiple ways you can get there. Do you prefer walking or public transportation?
Good job! You did it.
Ooo... Almost, but not fully correct! Try again.

items.content:
Another common work activity is answering frequently asked questions like:

- Where is the restroom?

- When is the check-out time?

- What is there to do in this city?

- Where and when is breakfast?

All these questions you have to know the answer to.

prompt.body: You are helping the guest at the desk and she asks you what facilities/ services you provide and have. You list them to her, but you also explain to her that if she would ever want to find them again, she could go to a place where all of them are listed. Where is that place?

content.body: Correct! This board, that most hotels have, list all of the facilities, services and where to find them. They sometimes even show a map of the city the hotel is in.
That's not correct! But you are very close...

items.content:
Oh no! A guest has a complaint about their room or the breakfast they had this morning. How will you help them?

It is never fun to deal with guests with complaints because you never know how they will react to your response. One of the main things you need to do is stay calm, take ownership and acknowledge that the guest has a problem, and let them know that you want to find a solution to the problem as much as them.

Ask them what they would like you to do for them and figure out if their request is reasonable or not, and if it is not, explain why you are not able to offer that to them. Also, don't promise them something that you are not able to do, such as a free room upgrade or a deduction on their total room price.

prompt.body: Explain in +/- 100 words, what you should do when a guest has a complaint.

values.value: The main thing you should do is stay calm. Don' try to take the guests his/her complaint personal and don't try to feel as if they are attacking you.The next thing you should do is listen well to their complaint and acknowledge the problem. Then get to the facts and offer the best solution you can.

content.body: The main thing you should do is stay calm. Don' try to take the guests his/her complaint personal and don't try to feel as if they are attacking you.The next thing you should do is listen well to their complaint and acknowledge the problem. Then get to the facts and offer the best solution you can.

items.content: To better understand the steps that have to be taken during the check-in process. Watch the video below!

items.caption: The Steps to the Hotel Check-in Process

items.content:
Checking out a guest is a very important activity for several reasons. It is the last time you will see the guests, so you have to make sure that once they step out of the hotel, you can be certain they had the best stay they could ask for.

Checking out a guest is much simpler than checking in a guest because you already did most of the work during the check-in!

You usually start by asking them which room they were in and how their stay was. (If at this point, the guest has a complaint, go to the 'complaints' scenario for more information.) Once they tell you that everything was well, you ask them if you are allowed to use the credit card that you have in your system to charge all the expenses. They usually answer yes, but if not, ask them how they would like to pay. Then you ask them for the room keys back and wish them a wonderful day and a safe flight back home!

content.body:
You: Hi there. Are you now?

Guest: Yes, I am sorry that we are a little late!

You: That is no problem. It was really here anyway. How was ?

Guest: Everything was great. Except that our food was very cold this morning during breakfast.

You: Oh, I am sorry to hear that! Did you let the know about it, this morning?

Guest: No. I wasn't a big deal, and there was other food to choose from.

You: Well, I am sorry again and letting them know about this afterward.

You: Will you be paying with your ?

Guest: Yes, that's fine!

You: Ok. So the total comes to 140, for the room, the breakfast for 3 mornings, minus this morning to compensate for the cold food, and the use of the gym.

Guest: That is very nice of you. Thank you very much!

You: No problem. I wish you a nice day and home!
busy
your stay
will be
checking out
credit card
a safe flight
breakfast crew
Good job! You did it.
Ooo... Almost, but not fully correct! Try again.

heading.content: Are you ready for hotel life? Let's find out!

items.content:
For the first-year students, level 3 and 4; make the assignment that applies to you.

For the second-year students, level 3; make the assignment that applies to you.

For the second-year students, level 4; make the assignment that applies to you.

If you did more than what was assigned to you, you can make the other exams as well, but this is not mandatory!

introduction.body:
Let's go over today's goals once more!

At the end of this class, I will...

  • ...better understand the role of the hotel reception

  • ...be able to help a guest with giving directions

prompt.body: Put these mixed up sentences in the right order.

content.body: 1. A shower. How much is the room?
1. Just this one bag.
1. Now, do you want a room with a bath or a shower?
1. It's actually across the street next to the bank. I hope you enjoy your stay.
1. Here's your key. Your room number is 655.
1. Just a single, please.
1. Yes, of course. We take Visa and Access. Could you sign the register, please?
1. Thank you. Goodnight.
1. Good evening. Can I help you?
1. Oh, one more thing. Where is the hotel car park?
1. Yes, please. Could I have a room for the night?
1. Of course. A single room or a double?
1. $85 for the room and that includes breakfast. Would you like to have dinner in the hotel?
1. No, thanks. Just breakfast, please. Can I pay by credit card?
1. No, just a signature. Do you have any luggage?
1. Yes, sure. Do you need my address, too?

prompt.body: When a guest comes to you with the question: ''How do I get to the city center?''. What should you ask?

content.body: Ask them how they would like to go?
By knowing if they want to walk or take the public transportation, you can give them more specific and detailed directions.
Ask them why they want to go there.

No, that's not correct. Asking them why they want to go, in that way, is intrusive and rude. But by rephrasing the question, and asking: ''Would you like to go to a specific shop or restaurant?'' you could ask them that instead.

prompt.body: Explain in +/- 100 words, what you should do when a guest has a complaint.

values.value: The main thing you should do is stay calm. Don' try to take the guests his/her complaint personal and don't try to feel as if they are attacking you.The next thing you should do is listen well to their complaint and acknowledge the problem. Then get to the facts and offer the best solution you can.

content.body: The main thing you should do is stay calm. Don' try to take the guests his/her complaint personal and don't try to feel as if they are attacking you.The next thing you should do is listen well to their complaint and acknowledge the problem. Then get to the facts and offer the best solution you can.

prompt.body: What is something you can offer if a guest has a complaint about the breakfast menu?

content.body: A room upgrade
New toiletries and towels
Free breakfast
A deduction of the breakfast fee

prompt.body: When handling a complaint, it is important to remember that...

content.body: ...no empathy should be shown
Definitely not the right answer. You should always show empathy.
...making excuses should be avoided
Correct! Don't try to justify or make an excuse for something that happened. This makes the guest not feel listened to and could result into more anger
...tell the guest you don't feel appreciated
This is not true. We learned that you should not feel personally attacked by the things guest say out of anger.
...you should not deal with complaints, only your manager
This is not the right answer. You can call management if the guest does not want to talk to you or the complaint is something you are not able to find a solution for.

prompt.body: When a guest comes to you with the question: ''How do I get to the city center?''. What should you ask?

content.body: Ask them how they would like to go?
By knowing if they want to walk or take the public transportation, you can give them more specific and detailed directions.
Ask them why they want to go there.

No, that's not correct. Asking them why they want to go, in that way, is intrusive and rude. But by rephrasing the question, and asking: ''Would you like to go to a specific shop or restaurant?'' you could ask them that instead.

Don' try to take the guests his/her complaint personal and don't try to feel as if they are attacking you.The next thing you should do is listen well to their complaint and acknowledge the problem. prompt.body: How to check someone in

content.body: You can go to room 529. If you take the elevator to the top floor, it will be in the left hall.
I would like to check-in!
Yes. Ofcourse, here you go!
No, that won't be necessary, thank you.
Under the name: Michaels. Can you find it?
Enjoy your stay sir and good bye.
Could I have your credit card for the expenses and a deposit?
Okay thank you. And good bye.
Yes, I found it. It is a stay for 7 nights without breakfast. Would you like breakfast?
Okay perfect, under what name did you make a reservation?
Good morning, how can I help you?

prompt.body: Explain the checking out procedure.

values.value:
Firstly, you ask for the room number and how their stay was. Then you ask them if you are allowed to charge the credit card they gave to you during check-in or if they have another way of paying. Then you charge them the way they would like to pay. Finally, you wish them a nice day and a safe flight back home.

Is your answer close to this? Good job!

Is your answer not close to this? Let's watch the video once more!

content.body:
Firstly, you ask for the room number and how their stay was. Then you ask them if you are allowed to charge the credit card they gave to you during check-in or if they have another way of paying. Then you charge them the way they would like to pay. Finally, you wish them a nice day and a safe flight back home.

Is your answer close to this? Good job!

Is your answer not close to this? Let's watch the video once more!

prompt.body: During the check-in process, what is the first question you ask the quest?

content.body: Good morning, how was your flight?
Yes! That is correct. You start with small talk, and then ask for their name.
Good morning, what is your name?
Close, you first start of with small talk, and then ask for their name to look them up in the system.
Good morning, what do you want?
This is of course not the righ answer, not to mention, quite rude.

items.content:
Here are some links to a game and a practice exam that you can do to improve on your Hotel General Vocab and to test your knowledge in today's class!

The link to the KAHOOT you can also do, but we will be doing that in class next week!

items.caption: Crossword Puzzle: General Hotel Vocab Practice

items.content:
The link above will bring you to an exam in Microsoft Forms. This exam is meant for the students that are confident enough in their skills and brain and have gone through all the material from today's class.

Log in with your student e-mail and you are good to go! Good luck and... ⬇️
Please go to the link below and let me know if you have any remarks, positive feedback, or critical feedback for me about today's class!

items.title: Padlet: What did we think of today's class?
